Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of 5-ALA Dosing for Fluorescence-Guided Resection of Malignant Glioma

Trial_Design.evidence: In a double-blind, randomised controlled trial, 21 patients with suspected malignant glioma were enrolled at a single center.

Participants.evidence: Participants aged 18-75 years with a Karnofsky Performance Scale score of ≥70% were randomised to receive 0.2, 2, or 20 mg/kg of 5-ALA.

Intervention.evidence: Participants aged 18-75 years with a Karnofsky Performance Scale score of ≥70% were randomised to receive 0.2, 2, or 20 mg/kg of 5-ALA.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the efficacy of different doses of five-aminolevulinic acid (5-ALA) for fluorescence-guided resection of malignant glioma.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the surgeon's perception of tumor fluorescence under violet-blue light, measured intraoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using block randomisation with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding included patients, surgeons, and outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 21 patients with suspected malignant glioma were enrolled at a single center.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The 20 mg/kg group showed the strongest fluorescence in tumor core and margins, correlating with cell density.

Funding.evidence: Funding: Sponsored by Medac, Hamburg, Germany.
